title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the biome most likely to be encountered at any latitude as desert.
The response identifies the biome most likely to be encountered at any latitude as desert.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain why the rate of carbon cycling is faster in a tropical wet forest than in a desert, such as any of the following:

· There would be faster rates of cycling of carbon in a tropical wet forest because there are higher rates of photosynthesis/respiration/productivity than in a desert due to increased precipitation and/or higher temperatures.

· Tropical rainforests have greater rates of decomposition than in a desert as a result of warmer temperatures and/or more precipitation.

· There would be lower rates of cycling of carbon in a desert because there are lower rates of photosynthesis/respiration/productivity/decomposition than in a tropical wet forest due to differences in temperature and/or precipitation.

The response explains why the rate of carbon cycling is faster in a tropical wet forest than in a desert, such as one of the following:

· There would be faster rates of cycling of carbon in a tropical wet forest because there are higher rates of photosynthesis/respiration/productivity than in a desert due to increased precipitation and/or higher temperatures.

· Tropical rainforests have greater rates of decomposition than in a desert as a result of warmer temperatures and/or more precipitation.

· There would be lower rates of cycling of carbon in a desert because there are lower rates of photosynthesis/respiration/productivity/decomposition than in a tropical wet forest due to differences in temperature and/or precipitation.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim based on evidence in the graph to support or refute the hypothesize that a temperate grassland will support agricultural crops more sustainably (decades rather than years) than a tropical wet forest, such as any of the following:

· Temperate grasslands have thick, rich soil that builds up for hundreds of years and serves as significant reservoirs of plant nutrients.

· The soil in tropical rainforests is relatively nutrient poor because of the rapid cycling of nutrients/its high level of acidity/or the significant quantity of nutrients stored as biomass.

· Most agricultural crops are descendants of native grasses and are best adapted to live in the soils of a temperate grassland biome, while the soil in tropical rainforests is relatively nutrient poor.

The response makes a claim based on evidence in the graph to support or refute the hypothesize that a temperate grassland will support agricultural crops more sustainably (decades rather than years) than a tropical wet forest, such as one of the following:

· Temperate grasslands have thick, rich soil that builds up for hundreds of years and serves as significant reservoirs of plant nutrients.

· The soil in tropical rainforests is relatively nutrient poor because of the rapid cycling of nutrients/its high level of acidity/or the significant quantity of nutrients stored as biomass.

· Most agricultural crops are descendants of native grasses and are best adapted to live in the soils of a temperate grassland biome, while the soil in tropical rainforests is relatively nutrient poor.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain how a species of small mammal on a remote island could have acquired the adaptation of larger average body size, such as any of the following:

· If there are no predators present, there is no selective pressure to hide, so a larger average body size would be selected for/larger individuals would survive and reproduce.

· If there are no large herbivores present, larger individuals can occupy the niche that might otherwise be occupied by larger herbivores. Larger individuals survive and pass their genes on to their offspring.

· Genetic mutation and natural selection occur over many generations, leading to a population of larger average body size over time.

The response explains how a species of small mammal on a remote island could have acquired the adaptation of larger average body size, such as one of the following:

· If there are no predators present, there is no selective pressure to hide, so a larger average body size would be selected for/larger individuals would survive and reproduce.

· If there are no large herbivores present, larger individuals can occupy the niche that might otherwise be occupied by larger herbivores. Larger individuals survive and pass their genes on to their offspring.

· Genetic mutation and natural selection occur over many generations, leading to a population of larger average body size over time.

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim using evidence that supports or opposes the proposal to build a biomass power plant within a temperate forest that will use the residues of wood processing to provide electricity for a new housing development, such as any of the following:

· This proposal should be supported. Processing wood into paper generates waste (e.g., leaves, bark, sawdust). Rather than being disposed of, this renewable resource could be burned to produce electricity in the proposed power plant.

· This proposal should be supported. Burning waste materials instead of harvesting timber protects trees and valuable ecosystem services.

· This proposal should be supported. Biomass is carbon neutral.

· The proposal should be opposed because new trees would need to be harvested if the waste supply runs out.

· This proposal should be supported. Processing wood into paper generates waste (e.g., leaves, bark, sawdust). Rather than being disposed of, this renewable resource could be burned to produce electricity in the proposed power plant.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe an advantage of generating electricity from a solar farm in a grassland rather than from a solar farm located in a desert, such as any of the following:

· Solar panel operation in a grassland would be more efficient at creating electricity because solar panels are most efficient at the lower temperatures found in a grassland.

· There is less risk of destroying species habitats/displacing species by building a solar farm in a grassland rather than in a desert.

· Placing solar panels in grasslands would enable multiple use of land for livestock grazing and shade crops.

· Sandstorms can damage solar panels in deserts.

The response describes an advantage of generating electricity from a solar farm in a grassland rather than from a solar farm located in a desert, such as one of the following:

· Solar panel operation in a grassland would be more efficient at creating electricity because solar panels are most efficient at the lower temperatures found in a grassland.

· There is less risk of destroying species habitats/displacing species by building a solar farm in a grassland rather than in a desert.

· Placing solar panels in grasslands would enable multiple use of land for livestock grazing and shade crops.

· Sandstorms can damage solar panels in deserts.

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not identify the dependent variable in the experiment, such as any of the following:

· The number of insect species counted in the leaf litter

· The diversity of insect species

The response identifies the dependent variable in the experiment, such as one of the following:

· The number of insect species counted in the leaf litter

· The diversity of insect species

title: Part I
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe the effect that soil moisture level would likely have on the results of the investigation, such as any of the following:

· Increased soil moisture would increase plant growth and increase the amount of leaf litter and insect diversity at the sites.

· Decreased soil moisture would decrease plant growth and decrease the amount of leaf litter and insect diversity at the sites.

· Excessive soil moisture could waterlog soils, killing plants and thereby decreasing insect diversity.

· Different insect species prefer different levels of soil moisture. Such differences could affect insect diversity in the litter.

The response describes the effect that soil moisture level would likely have on the results of the investigation, such as one of the following:

· Increased soil moisture would increase plant growth and increase the amount of leaf litter and insect diversity at the sites.

· Decreased soil moisture would decrease plant growth and decrease the amount of leaf litter and insect diversity at the sites.

· Excessive soil moisture could waterlog soils, killing plants and thereby decreasing insect diversity.

· Different insect species prefer different levels of soil moisture. Such differences could affect insect diversity in the litter.

title: Part J
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain how modifying the experiment to collect samples from new and old compost piles could alter the results of the experiment, such as any of the following:

· In older compost, the leaves have decomposed, which could impact the type of insect species that would inhabit the litter. Insect biodiversity may increase because there would be more organic material available.

· In newer compost, the leaves are more intact and there is less broken-down organic material available to the insects, so biodiversity may decrease.

· Insects have had more time to colonize an older sample, resulting in greater insect diversity.

The response explains how modifying the experiment to collect samples from new and old compost piles could alter the results of the experiment, such as one of the following:

· In older compost, the leaves have decomposed, which could impact the type of insect species that would inhabit the litter. Insect biodiversity may increase because there would be more organic material available.

· In newer compost, the leaves are more intact and there is less broken-down organic material available to the insects, so biodiversity may decrease.

· Insects have had more time to colonize an older sample, resulting in greater insect diversity.
